title.narrative: SAYWHAT SRHR for Students & Young People 2021-24
SAYWHAT SRHR for Students & Young People 2021-24

description.narrative: Intervention 1 : Strengthening of young people’s access to Sexual & Reproductive Health and Gender Based Violence This intervention shall have 3 key outputs of; -Ensuring availability of Sexual & Reproductive Health and Gender Based Violence content created by young people, -Young people’s access to accurate and quality information on Sexual & Reproductive Health and Gender Based Violence -Generation of evidence and up to date trending information on young people’s Sexual & Reproductive Health, Gender Based Violence and related issues. Outcome: Improved information management and decision making on Sexual & Reproductive Health and Gender Based Violence issues among young people Intervention 2: Increasing access and utilisation of Sexual & Reproductive Health and gender responsive services by young people This intervention shall have 3 key outputs of; -Ensuring access to a youth friendly referral pathway on Sexual & Reproductive Health and Gender Based Violence services by young people, -Increasing availability of a broad range of clinical, Gender Based Violence and legal Sexual Reproductive Health services, -Strengthened peer to peer support for young people to access Sexual & Reproductive Health and Gender Based Violence services Outcome: Increased access and utilisation of quality Sexual Reproductive Health and gender responsive health services and commodities by young people. Intervention 3 : Increasing young people’s participation and representation in SRH and GBV advocacy This intervention shall have 2 key outputs of; -Ensuring improved competences and capacities of young Sexual Reproductive Health activists, -Improved participation and coordination of young people in Sexual & Reproductive Health and Gender Based Violence Advocacy initiatives. Outcome: Improved operational environment that adequately supports and informs young people’s participation in Sexual & Reproductive Health and Gender Based Violence policy and programme development Intervention 4: Coordination of Sexual & Reproductive Health and Gender Based Violence campaigns by young people This intervention shall have 2 key outputs of; -Strengthened capacities of young serving organisations in the development of Sexual & Reproductive Health\Gender Based Violence choice messages for young people. -Coordinated young people’s voices on Sexual & Reproductive Health and Gender Based Violence Outcome: Amplified young voices on Sexual & Reproductive Health and Gender Based Violence choices

Saywhat has applied to Sida for funding of 33 million SEK to carry out the ("Action for Choice Phase 2") during the period 2021-2024.
The intervention aims to ensure that Young People are safe and enjoy high quality SRHR and GBV Services and Information by 1) Strengthening of young people’s access to SRHR and GBV information; 2) Increasing access and utilisation of SRH and gender responsive services by young people; and 3) Increasing young people’s participation and representation in SRH and GBV advocacy. Saywhat will work with the young people, line ministries and service providers.
The intervention is solely funded by the Embassy as core support and there will be no forwarding of funds.

Saywhat har ansökt Sida om finansiering på 33 miljoner SEK för att genomföra ("Action for Choice Phase 2") under perioden 2021-2024.
Insatsen syftar till att se till att unga människor är säkra och åtnjuter SRHR- och GBV-tjänster och information av hög kvalitet genom att 1) ??stärka ungdomars tillgång till SRHR- och GBV-information; 2) Öka tillgången och användningen av SRH och könsresponsiva tjänster för unga och 3) Öka ungdomars deltagande och representation i SRH och GBV-förespråkande. Saywhat kommer att fungera med ungdomar, ministerier och tjänsteleverantörer.
Insatsen finansieras enbart av ambassaden som kärnstöd och medel kommer inte att vidarebefordras till tredjepart.

participating-org.narrative: SAYWHAT/Students and Youth Working on Reproductive Health Action Team
SAYWHAT/Students and Youth Working on Reproductive Health Action Team

tag.narrative: 3.3 - By 2030, end the epidemics of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria and neglected tropical diseases and combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases and other communicable diseases.
3.3 - Senast 2030 utrota epidemierna av aids, tuberkulos, malaria och försummade tropiska sjukdomar samt bekämpa hepatit, vattenburna sjukdomar och andra smittsamma sjukdomar.

3.7 - By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.

3.7 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsovård, inklusive familjeplanering, information och utbildning, och att reproduktiv hälsa integreras i nationella strategier och program.
5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet, inklusive människohandel, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.
5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.

5.6 - Ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights as agreed in accordance with the Programme of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development and the Beijing Platform for Action and the outcome documents of their review conferences.

5.6 - Säkerställa allmän tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och reproduktiva rättigheter i enlighet med överenskommelserna i handlingsprogrammet från den internationella konferensen om befolkning och utveckling, Pekingplattformen samt slutdokumenten från respektive översynskonferenser.

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative:
The Action for Choice II project commenced on the first of September 2021. This is an extension of the first phase which aimed to Reduce SRH related mortality and morbidity among young people in 10 state universities of Zimbabwe. The second phase has a goal to ensure that Young People are safe and enjoy high-quality SRHR and GBV Services in higher learning institutions and surrounding communities in Zimbabwe.
Action for Choice II commenced during the COVID-19 lockdown when the country was under lockdown level 4. The subsequent restrictions resulted in 43% of activities being conducted virtually. The organisation was also affected by the new Omicron variant as it recorded 60% infection among the stuff leading to early closure of offices for the December break. This affected the implementation of flagship events such as the students' conference and the Condomize campaign.
Objective 1: Strengthening of young peoples access to SRHR and GBV information
Under this objective SAYWHAT reached a total of 108 640 young people. Students were mobilized to participate in creation of program content through Power Talks and Newsletters thereby enabling their access to SRHR and GBV information. Twelve Power Talks were produced and broadcasted in commemoration of the 16 days of activism against Gender-Based Violence reaching 7 700 people.
Key issues coming out of the various interactions with young people are (i) a lot of young women being abused in relationships even at colleges, (ii) young women and men have established networks of blessers who provide their daily needs for a glamorous trendy university lifestyle, (iii) menstrual health supplies are not readily available at colleges, (iv) mental health and substance use are areas of concern for students. (v) There is need for more free contraceptive planning services for young people.
To address some of these challenges SAYWHAT roped in the Friendship Bench team to support with mental health management. Some of the issues raised have since been included as the discussion points in the next Quarterly meetings with Focal Persons and Deans of Colleges as well as with the portfolio committees for both the Higher and Tertiary Education as well as the Health and Child Care scheduled for the Q2 of 2022. The peer education training and training of college health personnel has also included the matters raised in these various platforms. Population Services Zimbabwe, Zimbabwe National Family Planning Council (ZNFPC), City of Harare and Bulawayo have been engaged for service delivery partnerships.
During the implementation period, 8 Legal Talks Shows could not be implemented due to Omicron (COVID-19) outbreak towards year-end which affected engagement of facilitators. The outstanding Legal Talk shows will be implemented in the first quarter of 2022.
Objective 2: Increasing access and utilisation of SRH and gender responsive services by young people
The Call centre is facilitating SRH and GBV service access by young people through the referral system and medical vouchers. From September to December 2021, 1061, calls were received from young people with cases ranging from, mental health, family planning and education support requests. Of all the cases received, 89% were closed. new partnerships being established with the local authorities, ZNFPC, the Friendship Bench, Musasa, Zimbabwe Women Lawyers Association (ZWLA), After Rape Clinic (ARC) and other NGOs to support and respond to the requests coming through the call Centre In addition, 10 700 young people accessed integrated GBV, SRH and HIV services at college clinics. Services included family planning, counselling, HIV testing and management. The highest numbers were achieved under family planning.
SAYWHAT is also responding to SRH commodities shortages alerts coming through the call centre in different communities by getting in touch with the responsible local service providers to act. SYWHAT jointly with National AIDS Council (NAC) and ZNFPC responded to the call for shortages of condoms at Lupane State University and neighbouring communities
However, due to COVID-19 outbreak, several planned actions could not be implemented as more than half the SAYWHAT staff members had tested positive for COVID-19. These include the CONDOMIZE! Campaign, Physical Dialogues at Resource Centres, Social Media Dialogues, Virtual Legal Clinics, and Health and Career Guidance Days.
Objective 3: Increasing young peoples participation and representation in SRH and GBV advocacy
As a result of the 2021 SASI Debate Competition (implemented under A4C Phase 1), which emphasized the need to criminalize sexual harassment in Zimbabwe, the Joint Parliamentary Portfolio Committee on Higher and Tertiary Education and Committee on Gender commissioned a fact-finding mission and conducted consultative meetings across tertiary institutions in Zimbabwe. SAYWHAT mobilized the Peer Educators community across 16 tertiary institutions to participate in these meetings giving students an opportunity to freely share their grievances on Sexual Harassment. The consultations Report for the consultative process will be presented before parliament in February 2022 after which SAYWHAT will follow up with the respective committees on actions taken by government to address raised issues.
Other issues
Media Monitoring findings are informing decision making for the organization. Following media reports of condom and morning-after pill shortages in Bulawayo, SAYWHAT is working with AIDS Health Foundation (AHF) to scale up condom education and distribution in colleges in Bulawayo.
SAYWHAT did not manage to commission the baseline study which was planned for October 2021 due to late approvals by colleges. This was also a result of the suspension of face-to-face lectures where institutions opened in batches due to COVID-19. As a result, the activity was postponed to early 2022.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
